author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->
@chenspc This is an empty package.  Do you plan to actually develop it later?  In any case I'd recommend registering it only once it actually has some functionalities

@giordano sorry, didn't mean to spam the registry :) 

The package is meant for sharing some development code of our new electron microscope that is about to be installed. The other one #30147 was intended for data processing related code. I do plan to develop it, but at the moment everything is in small pieces of code on my local machine and private repos. 

It's probably not very different if I just leave it public without registering it. I didn't give it much thought about the distinction yesterday. I will close this two for now. 


----
I realised I actually don't know how to cancel it here.. could you help close it? thanks!

Just so you know, if you have collaborators who you are working on the project with or want people to use the package as it develops, you can tell people to `] add` and `] dev` links to the git repo. 

I would suggest having working with the git repo until the package is in a useable state, and then registering it after.
